Comment: You're trying to quote me on things I never said, and that's both ignorant and unfair.  I fully support the trans community. They deserve to be respected and treated equally, and to have their identities validated by society at large, and not to have their trans identities viewed as a mental illness that needs to be purged. But that's an issue with society as much as it's an issue with politics, and the trans community isn't the only community being attacked and rights stripped away slowly after over a decade of progress - decades for some - have regressed in just 100 days.  Trans rights are human rights and human rights will ALWAYS be necessary and important, but let's read the room. The average American cares that it's becoming increasingly unaffordable to make a living and maintain a roof over their head when literally 5 individuals control the vast majority of wealth in the nation and have effectively bought out the Presidency and turned it into an oligarchy. Not just that, but the oligarchy they've bought has systemically worked to strip away science and education, reverting all progress on improving the climate crisis and improving education and literacy to the masses, and slowly working to convert the nation into a Christo-Fascist nation that gives a rats ass about the planet and it's people all in the name of profit, all enabled by a corrupt Supreme Court and the woefully ignorant and uneducated.  Priorities.

Author: bin10pac

Comment: I never said that there was no sexism in Presidential elections.  Public perception is everything in politics, regardless of truth. And by the time Trump and Hillary were both campaigning to be President, Americans on both sides of the political spectrum had already become radicalized towards the far right and far left. Trump just amplified it.  But the bottom line is that Hillary wasn't trustworthy. The hype of her being the first female Presidential candidate was correct and deserved, but while the right championed her as a hallmark moment for social progress, the right was attacking it as an attack on all women being too emotional. Between that, being the husband of Bill Clinton, and all the speculation as to how Hillary became favored by DNC as the Democratic frontrunner over Bernie Sanders, how she handled Benghazi and that bullshit laptop scandal, she had a lot working against her that contributed to 100 million eligible citizens skip voting period.   As for Kamala, she wasn't popular, period. Though she was named an early front-runner for the nomination in 2020, she dwindled in popularity by the time all the candidates began debating each other and was among the first few candidates to suspend their campaign. Her campaign for 2024 wasn't very solid, but that's on Biden and the Democratic party just as much as it is on her. She ran largely on Biden's policies instead of her own. She largely focused on what Trump was going to do and not enough on what she was going to do. Her campaign didn't allow Tim Walz to effectively campaign for her, either, and he ended up looking like a joke after he went up against JD Vance.
